Digging for 14,000 Years

Visit an Archaeological Dig at One of the Oldest Known Settlements in North America

Travel back in time to 14,000 years ago. Enormous ice sheets cover most of Canada. Giant ground sloths and sabre-toothed cats roam the plains of what is now the southern United States. After crossing Beringia, the landmass that connects Asia with Alaska, humans began to travel southward along the resource-rich coastline.

We have scant evidence of people from this time period, but an archaeological site in coastal British Columbia has cracked open a door into this Ice Age world. Scroll through the archaeological excavation on Triquet Island—layer by layer—and uncover one of the oldest repeatedly occupied settlements in North America.

Scroll to Explore

The Excavation

An expert team of archaeologists spent weeks carefully sifting and examining more than five cubic meters of excavated material. That's equivalent to half of a cement mixing truck of soil, sand, clay, and rocks—all excavated by hand. The archaeologists separated artifacts, animal bones, and other evidence of human habitation, and meticulously recorded the exact sediment layer where each item originated. We zoomed in to a three-meter deep by one-meter wide wall to profile the deepest section at the archaeological site.

Next Article

(Un)stable Sea Levels

If you could travel back in time 14,000 years, you wouldn’t recognize the shape of British Columbia’s coastline. Vancouver is under a glacier. A vast dry plain takes the place of Hecate Strait between Haida Gwaii and the mainland. Sea levels rise and fall as glaciers grow and shrink, and as tectonic plates shift. The area around Triquet Island is an exception. Through a serendipitous combination of factors, sea levels in this area of the Central Coast stayed relatively stable, which has created a unique opportunity for archaeologists.

Next Article

The Shifting Story of Bones

The deeper, older layers contain mostly bones 3 from sea mammals, such as seals and sea lions. In contrast, the shallower layers reveal a shift toward a fishier diet for people. In more recent times, herring, salmon, rockfish, and lingcod played a more prominent role as technologies and culture changed.

Next Article

Volcano Glass Trade

Obsidian 4, a type of volcanic glass, was a precious material. Obsidian cutting instruments can be sharper than a surgeon’s blade. But you need a volcano to make obsidian and the closest source to Triquet Island is at Anahim Lake more than 200 kilometers away. Enter trade. Coastal peoples traded resources for obsidian that interior peoples could not access; such as the valuable fish oil from a silvery smelt called eulachon.

Next Article

Oral History

Listen to William Housty from the Heiltsuk Nation describe how the archaeological discoveries from Triquet Island reaffirm the Heiltsuk oral history passed down over generations. Interview by Christie Taylor, as part of the Science Friday podcast.

The Bottom?

Smaller test cores show that there are layers of older clay below the anvil stone 6, although no artifacts have been found in these layers. However, recent analysis from Hakai Institute geoscientists showed that Triquet Island was glacier-free around 16,800 years ago. Even older settlement sites in the region are therefore not out of the realm of possibility. The archaeology story continues.
